awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Affordable point-of-use water disinfection through mass-produced nano-silver embedded paper filters
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focuses on the research and development of an antimicrobial nanoparticle filter paper for low-cost point-of-use water purification.  The proposed project will develop an antimicrobial paper water purifier, packaged like a coffee filter, to be distributed through retail channels. This project will offer safe water to many communities throughout the world. 

This SBIR Phase II project will advance the development of a process using large-scale paper machinery and similar reel-to-reel processes to manufacture low-cost nano-metal functionalized materials, such as nanosilver filter paper. Phase II objectives include: (i) optimize the process to reduce materials and other costs, increase flow rate, and maintain high-quality performance, (ii) demonstrate a more robust filter system by mitigation of water chemical and microbiology variability through improved formulation and formal determination of product shelf-life, (iii) demonstrate production at pilot and industrial speeds and output levels, while validating a non-destructive quality control program, and (iv) integrate third-party product safety certification tests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Disclaimer

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

Key outcomes of the NSF SBIR Phase II and IIb research and development activity are industrial scale production and formalized quality control for Folia’s patent-pending nano-silver filter paper for a consumer goods water filter for antimicrobial point-of-use water purification. 

 

1. Proven, repeat industrial-scale paper coating

2. Formalized quality control systems

3. Validated filter paper and product design performance with real world consumer commercial sales and product feedback

4. Robust industrial process understanding covering real world application engineering required for implementation on many different types of industrial coating machinery

Additional accomplishments include:

•   Process patents issued in multiple countries

•   Anti-viral 3-ply face masks: completed all research and development, repeat industrial manufacturing, certification testing, and regulatory requirements for an antiviral 3-ply face mask during COVID. Folia’s masks kill 99.97% of SARS-CoV-2 on the surface in 1 hour (ISO 18184).  Industrial volumes of face masks were manufactured with repeat manufacturing and quality control.  



Broader/Commercial  Impacts:

​​More than 2 billion people don’t have access to clean drinking water. As the leading cause of hospitalizations in emerging countries, germs in drinking water account for 1.2 million deaths every year. The world needs a solution to sustainably achieve U.N. Sustainable Development Goal 6.1: universal access to safe and affordable drinking water for all. But existing solutions are neither affordable nor accessible to the people who need them most.

Folia Materials is a B2B materials company with a patented process to use paper machines to make nanomaterials at the large scale and penny costs of paper mills, commercializing a mass-market antimicrobial water purifier for export to emerging markets starting with S/SE Asia. Folia's flagship product is the Folia Filter, a simple, antimicrobial paper water filter packaged like a coffee filter that retails at 20 cents for 20 liters of safe-germ free water. 

 Folia Filters are the world's first water filters that cost pennies and not dollars. Folia Filters create a new ~$10B sub-category of consumer packaged goods (CPG) water purifier with the performance and price per liter of a $20-200 durable good appliance water purifier, with the price point, distribution, and sales channels of mass-market grocery store staples like soap, shampoo, and SIM cards. They are a 75-95% savings compared to bottled water, which is a $58B market in emerging markets alone. This lets us sell to working class families in emerging markets earning $2-10 a day, and collectively spending $5T on grocery staples. No other water purification product exists that can achieve the same price point as other grocery store items while meeting consumer requirements. 

​​This project allowed Folia Materials to scale the paper coating and manufacturing process from bench to industrial-scale. Working at industrial partners’ manufacturing facilities, Folia Materials has completed repeat manufacturing from raw materials through industrial paper coating and converting to finished packaged product at the pennies unit manufacturing costs required for mass-market grocery products.

Subsidiary Folia Water Global (FWG) was spun out to focus on commercializing the Folia Water Filter as a mass market grocery retail consumer health staple. Unilever and Aqua for All sponsored a market entry pilot into Bangladesh that proved product-market fit with over 100,000 filters sold from 2,500 stores. FWG is currently expanding to 10,000 stores to attract a national consumer goods distributor, prior to international expansion through consumer goods master distributors. National scale distribution and sales requires industrial scale manufacturing with formalized quality control which has been successfully achieved with this funding.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2023
Modified by: Theresa A Dankovich
